description.narrative: The IDH Coffee program is committed to finding ways in which the increasing world demand for coffee can be met sustainably. The program fosters global multi-stakeholder alignment on key sustainability issues, and seek to embed socially and environmentally friendly production techniques into the coffee supply chain. IDH convenes a multi-stakeholder platform across the coffee sector (the Global Coffee Platform , bringing together a range of industry players in a pre-competitive environment. This is a global partnership model that has the potential to bring sustainable coffee production to scale, and to improve the livelihoods of millions of coffee farmers worldwide. Working alongside partners from industry and trade, from governments, NGOs and standard-setting organizations across the sector, IDH promotes an approach that is both collaborative and bottom-up. The program focuses on applying local experience gained from field-level projects to the whole global sector – aiming to create a favorable environment for all key players, and to align investments in producer support programs. This emphasis on sector alignment, innovation, and local knowledge is reflected in the broad public-private partnership agenda. Collaboration at every level offers the best means of embedding socially and environmentally friendly practices into the global supply chain. This in turn offers the best means of meeting the rising global demand for coffee on a sustainable basis, and helping 4.3 million coffee producing families across the globe to become more resilient.

The program expenditure refers to: the payables to Implementing Partners for program implementation costs (IDH enters multi-year agreements with private and other implementing partners to execute the implementation of program activities in the field) and the IDH internal expenditures in the program development. Due to confidential agreements with some of the implementing partners, IDH reserves the right to publish organizations names, data and other relevant information. Aggregated results will be published on an aggregated commodity/landscape program level.

title.narrative: Website of the IDH Coffee Program
Representation and commitment of key-stakeholders in multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions

description.narrative: The indicator score is provided by a self-assessment performed by all stakeholders that are involved in the multi-stakeholder processes associated with the program or landscape. On an annual basis, all stakeholders that are active in the processes receive a request to complete a brief electronic questionnaire. The assessment is done through a set of statements focusing on the satisfaction, representation and commitment of the multi-stakeholder processes and coalitions as part of the IDH programs.

title.narrative: Satisfaction about the effectiveness of multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions associated with the program

description.narrative: The perceived satisfaction by the participating stakeholders (i.e. private sector, government, NGOs) of the multi-stakeholder process or coalitions in which they participate.

title.narrative: Development of and compliance with voluntary and legal standards on sustainable commodity production

description.narrative: Name and qualitative description about the legal requirement or voluntary standards that have been agreed upon or applied by the sector as a result of IDH interventions and its background; If possible: indicate the number or percentage of companies and/or producers complying with the legal requirement/standard in the sector or landscape.

title.narrative: Changes at policy and regulatory level contributing to increased sustainability of commodity production and improved management of natural resources

description.narrative: Qualitative description explaining the background and progress of the changes in policies, regulations, and/or enforcement of these as a result of IDH interventions

comment.narrative: Annual 2019 target is adjusted from 4 (Annual Plan 2019) to 1 here because the aim of the program was to reach 5 policy changes between 2016 and 2020. The program aims to influence policy changes on smallholder resilience, water use reduction in Vietnam, and responsible agro-input use in Indonesia, Vietnam and Uganda. This leaves limited space for reaching policy changes. Therefore - and because we have already reached our targets - we decided to focus on what we could realistically achieve in 2019 on policy changes within these topics and countries.

title.narrative: Adoption rate by producers/workers/ community members of improved practices

description.narrative: Measurement takes place 6 months after the training took place, performed by the Implementing Partner (guidance from POs is needed);Typical approaches look at 3-5 key practices that drive productivity, quality, safety or natural resource conservation or restoration practices. These should be defined specifically for each crop/program including specific criteria for adoption. Data collection could be based on a combination of on farm registration via farmer field books and observations in the field on a sample basis.

title.narrative: # of trainers, auditors and/or government staff trained by the program

description.narrative: Several programs have indicated they will develop curricula or guidance for service delivery or extension of good practices. This indicator looks at whether this is being achieved, and whether the next step is taken, being the training of trainers and auditors to use these deliverables.

comment.narrative: Master Trainers trained under national platforms: 256 216 men and 53 women

title.narrative: # of processing facilities with sustainable production practices and social standards applied

description.narrative: The number of processing facilities that are involved in the program that apply sustainable production practices and social standards.

title.narrative: # of producers/workers / community enterprises reached by service delivery

description.narrative: The number of producers/ workers/community enterprises that have been offered services other than training within the scope of the program. These services could be: 1. Input services – planting material, fertilizer, crop protection products/ pesticides. 2. Financial services – inputs on credit, cash advances, pre-harvest finance; 3. Value adding services – services that add value to the product of smallholder farmers, such as mechanization (use of tractors), processing, post-harvest handling and storage services.

comment.narrative: Financial service delivery: 12,159; Input service delivery: 5,530; Planting material service delivery: 8,813 Irrigation service delivery: 8 ; Direct sourcing service delivery: 96
Men: 14,011; Women: 5,733 (Financial service delivery: 4,387; Input service delivery: 8,655; Planting material service delivery: 6,703; Irrigation service delivery: 60; Direct sourcing: 98)

title.narrative: # of producers/workers/community members trained on key subjects for sustainable production, environmental and social sustainability issues

description.narrative: it is important to capture the following information: The number of producers or workers or community members trained; Split by gender; The number and frequency of individual training events The topic of the training

comment.narrative: Men: 18,858; Women: 7,286. Number of training events: 3,743

description.narrative: it is important to capture the following information:How many people (trainers, auditors, government staff) have been trained based on a dedicated curriculum aimed at improved sustainability in the sector; The number of individual training events (similar to training of farmers/workers)

comment.narrative: In 2018, we installed eight drip-irrigation systems with precision-farming technology in the Acom project in Vietnam. These were installed under the 50% subsidy from IDH, after showing that there is no business case for irrigation in Vietnam. For the next round of installations, Acom will actively work with VnSAT to leverage their funding for the project, in addition to to IDH funding.

title.narrative: Result Area 1 - Change in business practice
Private sector (sustainability) investments in the program

description.narrative: The actual realized eligible private sector investments per program (in €)

comment.narrative: The ratio between the public investments by IDH and realized eligible private sector investments is 1:2.2
The ratio between the public investments by IDH and realized eligible private sector investments is 1:2.5
The ratio between the public investments by IDH and realized eligible private sector investments is 1:3.1

description.narrative: The aggregated market share of all private sector partners in the program in terms of the annual volumes of the respective commodity produced

comment.narrative: Roasters: 25; Traders: 40. 40% of the world volume of coffee is traded via traders that are members of GCP; 25% of coffee is bought by roasters that are part of GCP.

title.narrative: IDH participation in relevant landscape and or commodity platforms

description.narrative: Number (#)of platforms where the IDH program is playing an active role and Qualitative description about the platform/round table/coalition objective and the role played by IDH and how it can positively influence either directly or indirectly our program activities.

title.narrative: Business cases developed within the IDH program to show the potential of sustainable practices

description.narrative: The number and description of business cases that have been developed within the IDH program to demonstrate to the private sector the potential of sustainable practices adopted and implemented by other organizations

comment.narrative: 1.Ugacof and Grow More Seeds ; 2.Channelling food crop services through service infrastructure (Smallholder resilience

Annual 2019 target is adjusted from 6 (Annual Plan 2019) to 1 here is because the aim of the program was to reach 6 business cases between 2016 and 2020. Because we already reached our overall program target in 2018, we decided to focus on what we could realistically achieve in 2019.
